awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative: Winning the Internet Lottery: Growing Income Inequality, Social Class,  and Susceptibility to Cybercrime
awd_abstract_narration:
As the digital divide closes and more groups have access to the Internet, cybersafety is an increasingly relevant issue. With the connectivity provided by the Internet comes an inherent interdependency between devices connected to the Internet. Compromised devices are used in various forms of cybercrime (e.g., spam campaigns) that can affect the Internet as a whole. Thus, to increase cybersecurity, it is important to understand the ways and extent to which certain groups may be more susceptible to Internet crime. Previous studies have focused on how factors such as age, gender, occupation, and level of STEM background affect one?s susceptibility to Internet crime (i.e., phishing attacks), however little work has focused on how social class factors into Internet crime susceptibility. 

This project focuses on understanding new sociological factors that may render particular groups more or less likely to be affected by cybercrime (in particular, phishing attacks that highlight opportunities for economic advancement). 

The expected results from this project impact both the fields of cybersecurity and sociology. From a cybersecurity perspective, understanding whether particular demographics are disproportionately affected by online attacks can lead to: 1) efforts for prevention (e.g., Internet Service Providers that offer government subsidized broadband access can also provide cybersafety training); and 2) the identification of the spawning point of a cybercrime ecosystem, which if caught and addressed early, can make cyberspace at large more secure. Sociologically speaking, attention to whether social class influences susceptibility to cybercrime helps to highlight some of the previously understudied consequences of economic inequality.

por.por_cntn:
The digital divide is closing, leaving greater numbers of citizens with internet access. Yet technological divides still remain as certain subsectors of the population have greater access to skils, techniques, and knowledge that help them to navigate the internet more efficiently and carefully. These variations have both social and cybersecuity implications. As technology becomes a more ubiquitous part of everyday life, risks of cybersecurity increase as more and more devices are interconnected. This interconnection leads to risks that devices and the internet itself may become compromised through cybercrime.

Existing research has examined multiple variables to assess what sort of social or cultural factors may exacerbate or minimize susceptibilty to internet crime. So far researchers have studied gender, age, occupation, and STEM proficiency to assess whether these factors affect one's likelihood of falling prey to internet scams. Our research considered the role of social class in scam susceptibility, as we expected this might serve as an additional variable that could compromise users' ability to avoid cybercrime. 

Following this, we attempted to compile a sample of 60 individuals from different class backgrounds--20 poor, 20 middle class, and 20 upper class. (Final n for the project was 56.) We found respondents by frequenting public locales in Atlanta that were likely to attract respondents from various class backgrounds. 

We emailed participants once a week for four weeks, beginning on the date of recruitment. Each email included the URL of a well-known website, evaluation instructions, and a link to a website usability evaluation survey on SurveyMonkey.com. Each respondent was instructed to evaluate the same four websites in the same order. In parallel, we conducted a phishing campaign where we emailed respondents phishing messages that offered the promise of immediate payout if they click a link to access our server and enter their credit card information (or other personal financial information). Each email contained slightly different URLs to enable respondent differentiation. The personal financial information was validated coarsely (e.g., ensure that the credit card number entered has the correct number of digits), and encrypted using SHA-3 on the user's side with JavaScript functions. Once we determined who had and had not replied to the phishing attacks, we analyzed this data using a regression analysis. This allowed us to pinpoint whether social class as a variable influenced individuals' likelihood of being susceptible to email phishing attacks. 

Contrary to our expectations, social class was not a statistically significant factor that affected susceptibilty to internet scams. We plan to build on existing sociological theories to consider what other factors could explain variation in susceptibility to cybercrime.
